4:19 sums it up for ventures that you want to bank on (ie.e considering and responding to feedback in spite of your artistic sensibilities) which is a good thing for the end products of one venture (a popular consumer product), but not a good thing for the end product of the other (popular art, which is a popular consumer product, but not good art). It is like a Russian capitalist told me, "No one cares about their YouTube content, it is all about making money!" (though growing up in the Russian Black Market, he had some very bad ideas about making money - like faking scientific papers with a word-scrambling program (papers which other scientists are charged to read, hence 'making money')... very bad... wasting the time and energy of others... Black Market thinking... (not to disparage 'Black' - let's just call it the Criminal Market, though in Soviet Russia and after, that was the only way to survive, "You could not even get a nail without knowing someone")... The problem with MVP mentality is that most of the time Business types are too tight with the $$$ when it comes time to move past the MVP.  Most "Entrepreneur" types don't understand the concept of building in the ability to change or expand. This creates a situation where "minor" changes can cost more time and money than the MVP itself did.

My Pivot is a little rusty.
I have been on Etsy since 2013 and selling cards and prints of my artwork since 2005. I have never had a bad review on etsy. However the income from it isn't enough to even cover material costs. I have always had a minimum wage day-job, because I am too slow to ever have a better job.
When I was working on artwork that people were buying but I didn't necessarily like I was criticised by someone, they said that work that wasn't made for art sake wasn't worth it. So I always worked on what I wanted, what I wanted to buy, what I wanted to make. Yeah I have a good audience and lot of repeat customers but still, it doesn't make money.
The thing is I have had ideas and thoughts about this "pivot" for a long time. I have known what changes I need to make. I have been putting things off with doubt that I will ever be successful.

Watching this video this morning has felt like being hit in the face with a wet mackerel. I know what to do. I know what I need to do. With all my might I will get this rust pivot moving. Where's the WD40?

Far out. You listening to this intro EA? Who am I kidding that would take some self reflection.

It seems sad to me that someone might have to go from "I think the world would be a better place with X in it, I want a world with X, so I'm going to make X" but then not enough people want enough X to pay enough for it that that first person can spend their time making X and still survive, so they're faced with the choice of either do what everybody else wants and survive but give up on the thing that motivated them to act in the first place, or else die trying to do what they think is objectively the best thing.


It's why I've never commercialized any of my important projects. I want to make these things that are important to me, and I don't want to end up in the position of having to abandon them because they're not important enough to others. So I do what other people want for a living, and try to also find time to make the things that are important to me for me own sake, not as a business venture I'm trying to live off of.
